div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria weekly..as under for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Oriental Railways Express Service for Vienna, Berlin, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Saturday at 4 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUTH (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MERSINA, calling fortnightly at LARNACA (Cyprus) and continuing from Beyrout in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardahelles, Gallipoli anf Constantinople.
The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednesdays at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sedan Government Railways express service to Khartoum.

Mail Steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sina), Yambo and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah and Aden. For further information refer to the Co.'s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Fort Said, Suez or to THOS. COOK and SON (Eygypt) Ltd., HAMBURG-AMERIEA REISE-BUREAU or other Tourist Agencies.

div.head: ENGLAND IN EGYPT.
div.p:
In a review of Mr. Blunt's latest book on Egypt, the "Manchester Guardian" suggested that Sir Charles Dilke was accused by Mr. Blunt "of bartering Egypt to Gambetta's financial friends in exchange for the commercial treaty with France upon which our Under-Secretary had set his heart." Sir Charles replies to this statement in the issue

of our contemporary of last Thursday, and states that there is no foundation for the suggestion:

On many occasions, he continues, the late Sir Ellis Ahsmead-Bartlett introduced the allegation into his speeches in the House of Commons and into articles written by him for "England" and other journals. In replying to him in the House I set forth the facts as I now repeat them.

Without offering an opinion on the historical problem whether the Joint Note was or was not a necessary or a prudent consequence of the Cave mission, the Goschen mission, and the dual control, I have to say that it was the act of the Cabinet before I became a member of that body, and that, owing to my absence in Paris as chairman of the Royal Commission for the commercial treaty with France, I did not—as I otherwise should have done—hear of the negotiation until it was complete. Egyptian affairs were not discussed between Mr. Gambetta and myself. So far was I, moreover, from having "set my heart" upon the negotiation of a commercial treaty that it is known to my colleagues who were with me in Paris, all of whom are living, as is the then head of the Commercial Department, through whom we communicated with the Foreign Office and the Board of Trade upon the details, that I had from the first a disinclination to make a treaty and a preference for a most-favoured-nation arrangement. This I hoped would follow after we had obtained by discussion all the improvements in the French tariff as to the advantages of which we thought we could convince the Government of France.

In the House of Commons I went out of my way during the continuance of the prolonged negotiations to declare that I would not sign a treaty which did not fulfil two main conditions—(a) that it should be a further improvement on the whole over the improved state of things which had followed the reductions of tariff later than those of the Cobden Treaty, and (b) also should not sacrifice any principal branch of British trade.
The first condition was fulfilled as a result of the negotiations, but the second, though accomplished as regards the best Sheffield cutlery and certain other constituents of our export trade.

The great prolongation of the negotiations undoubtedly led our colleagues of the French High Commission under two successive French Administrations to believe that we intended to sign a treaty. It was publicly admitted on both sides that we were in a position to sign a treaty which would be on the whole defensible. The extraordinary deration of the negotiations were caused by the fact that most of the Continental Powers were negotiating with France "behind" us, as the phrase goes. With their representatives we were also in daily relations. As concessions were made for which certain interests in France pressed and which concerned chiefly British trade, our French colleagues granted these in their Swiss and other negotiations. At the last, when they signed treaties with Switzerland and several other Powers, the French Government came face to face with the necessity for either giving us all these favourable changes of their tariff in a most favoured-nation law or treating us in an unfriendly fashion, which there was nothing to warrant. For some time it was thought that our refusal to sign would be visited upon our trade by such extended to us for a short time by Spain. Wisdom, however, prevailed in the French Legislature, and (after I had finally broken off the negotiations, and, the other treaties having been signed by France, a pause had followed) a law was passed with singular rapidity by which there was extended to us that most-favoured-nation treatment which has continued to the present time; although the lowest scale of duty has been raised for all Powers in the intervening years. At no time was the Egyptian policy of either Cabinet allowed to have a bearing upon the commercial relation of the Powers.

div.head: Drowned.
div.p: A native child, aged 6 years, was drowned yesterday in one of the reservoirs of Ali Bey Tcrgoman's mill at Boulac.

div.head: The Municipal Palace.
div.p: The question of the erection of a new Municipal Palace for Alexandria has been postponed until the autumn.

div.head: Fatal Scorpion Sting.
div.p: A little native girl, named Nahiba, who was stung by a scorpion in Rue Kom el Cheikh Salama, has died from the effects.

div.head: A Foundling.
div.p: An abandoned child was discovered yesterday in Sharia Abdin. It has been taken into a private hospital, where it will be well cared for.

div.head: Carriage Accident.
div.p: On Wednesday evening towards 7 o'clock a Nasrieh tram overturned a carriage in Sharia Clot bey, completely wrecking it and seriously injuring the driver, who was immediately transferred to hospital in a desperate condition.

div.head: Kanka Asylum.
div.p: The construction of the new lunatic asylum at Kanka will be commenced immediately and will be actively carried on. The total cost of the establishment to the Government is estimated at about L.E. 110,000.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: The following particulars of bubonic plague throughout Egypt were recorded during the past 24 hours: — 1 admission and 1 death in hospital at Samallout and 1 death at Damanhour outside of hospital. 15 patients remain under treatment.

div.head: Coptic Bazaar Tragedy.
div.p: The Aix Tribunal has acquitted le Bihan, junior, who was accused with his father of the murder of the Chauffeur Leporcq, which took place in their house two months ago. As already reported Bihan senior was acquitted a month ago.

div.head: Public Health Department.
div.p: Acting on the suggestion of the Director General of this Department, the Ministry of the Interior has appointed Mohamed Effendi Amin Chakib as veterinary surgeon of the 4th class, and Jean Gallat as dispenser of the 2nd class to the hospital at Port Said, dating from 13th June.

div.head: Births and Deaths.
div.p: During the week ending the 1st instant, 496 births, of which 7 were of European parentage, and 813 deaths, of which 27 were Europeans,were registered in Cairo. 645 of these deaths were of children under 5 years of age. The following are the principle causes of death, with the number of victims:—Dyphtheria 8, 10, typhoid 3, measles 79, small pox 1, erysipelas 1 and fever1.

div.head: Accidents.
div.p: A spirit lamp being carelessly handled is again responsible for serious injuries received by Mohamed Afifieficier, at Boulac yesterday evening at about 9 o'clock. It appears that he thoughtlessly placed the lamp close to an open can of petrol which exploded, causing great damage. While crossing the railway line near Helouan, Borai Farraga was run over by a train belonging to the Delta Light Railways Death was instantaneous. A man was discovered by the police at Old Cairo yesterday lying in the roadway in a moribund condition, suffering from terrible wounds in the back and chest. On the way to hospital the injured man died, and as yet no clue as to his identity or the cause of his injuries is forthcoming. A post mortem examination will be held at the hospital.

div.head:
THE COTTON MARKET.
KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT
div.p: LIVERPOOL, June 27.
The demand for Spot Egyptians still continues small, and quite of a retail character, being scarcely sufficient to test prices. Quotations are nominally 3/16d plb. down.
In Futures a small business has been done, and the following are the latest values:— June 10.24 Sep. 10.21 Dec. 10.14 Mar. 10.11 July 10.22 Oct. 10.20 Jan. 10.11 Aug 10.23 Nov. 10.18 Feb. 10.11

American Futures. The Market this week has been fairly active, and prices experienced first a sharp decline, and later a more important recovery. To-day's closing values are, for the current month 3 1\2 points, the other Old Crop positions 6@ 7 1/2 points, and the various New Crop positions 7@ 10 points higher than those of last Thursday.

The decline was chiefly due to continued favorable crop reports and an absence of any speculative support; the subsequent recovery in values was due to reaction, manipulation; and professional support on the "Bull" side aided by some sensational reports as to the unfavorable prospects of the crop in face of the official highly improved weather conditions. No one at present can form any intelligent forecast of the market because there is no public element of any weight operating in any of the markets. There are supposed to be influential forces at work here which control the Old Crop positions, and another set operation upon the same lines in New York and New Orleans with the usual professional traders who ride upon the backs of these cliques. div.head: OPENING OF THE CASSA.
div.p: The Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio will open definitely to-morrow morning. Possibly the bank may open for a few minutes this evening, in order that the technical legal necessity for avoiding the lapse of fifteen days after shutting the doors should be complied with. The Syndicate to advance the £300,000 has been formed. The liquidation is being carried on under the auspices of the National Bank of Egypt. This bank has appointed two liquidators who will be the executive officers of the liquidation. They will be members of a committee of four persons. The other two members of this committee are being appointed by the board of directors of the Cassa di Sconto. In the case of there being an equality of votes between the four members of this committee, the casting vote will be in the hands of a delegate of the Governor or Sub Governor of the National Bank of Egypt.

div.head: TROUBLES IN CAIRO.
div.p: A number of firms in Cairo, mostly in the Mousky quarter of the capital, are in difficulties, but the centre of gravity in these cases is in Manchester. The difficulties can be tided over if patience is exercised until the cotton crop has been financed and money begins to come in after October. It is not reasonable to expect that in the middle of summer, arrangements should be brought to an abrupt termination.

div.head:
ENGLISH COMPANIES IN EGYPT.
RESPONSIBILITY OF DIRECTORS.
div.p: The excellent resumé on the liability of Directors under the Companies (English) Act of 1900, which appeared in your issue of yesterday and its applicability to non-British Directors domiciled abroad, will be appreciated by those who have followed the efforts of your journal to throw some light on this obscure question.

The main points at issue appear to be whether the British Consular Court in Egypt is possessed of the power to try cases against non-British Directors, or whether that jurisdiction lies with the mixed Tribunals, and whether a criminal action can be maintained in either court.

As regards the last point, it may be very seriously doubted if the British Consular Courts would in any case assume the responsibility ot trying even British subjects in criminal cases arising under the Companies Act of 1900. When one remembers the difficulties which had to be surmounted in England before the then Attorney General could be induced to take action against Whittaker Wright, and the numerous failures which have resulted from actions in England against Directors since the date in which the last Act came into force, one can hardly anticipate any keenness on the part of the British Consulate in Egypt to assume a liability which it may very reasonably be pleaded lies with the High Courts of Justice in England.
It would appear, however, that civil actions for damages against the Directors will have an equally good hearing in either the British Consular Courts or in the mixed Tribunals.

The law under which the Companies we are discussing are formed, enacts that each Director must inter-alia either himself, or through his agent, have signed and filled with the Registrar of Companies his consent in writing, to act as a Director. The Director is therefore bound by the Articles of Association which is registered with the memorandum: and it is difficult to understand how he can in any Court of Law plead any exemption from his contract. One may feel safe therefore, in leaving the decision with the mixed Tribunals.

Several companies registered in England have recently on the insistance of shareholders in Egypt transferred the direction to this country; and it may reasonably be supposed that before consenting to such transfer the English Directors have taken counsel's opinion on the subject, and have safeguarded the interests of their sharedolders in every way.

Therefore in the words of your contributor we may confidently anticipate that the non British Director in Egypt "will not be able to avail himself of the benefit of British law and at the same time, by a lotal technicality, be enabled to rid himself of all his obligations thereunder.

div.head: CASINO SAN STEFANO.
div.p: La saison bat son plein au Casino San Stefano. Hier la jolie terrasse était comble d'un monde élégant goûtant l'excellente musique de l'orchestre Bracale.

Sous peu aura lieu le début des 4 solistes de ehant, engagés à Milan pour la saison. Nous acrons donc le plaisir d'entendre le soprano dramatique Mlle Pitirollo, le contralto Mlle Finzi, sœur de l'excellente artiste qui a eu tant de succès au Zizinia l'hiver passé, le ténor Santini et le bariton Barbieri.

div.head:
CASSEL AND CASSA.
LONDON OPINION.
(Gazette's Special Service.)
div.p: London, Friday.

The opinion in financial circles in the City is that Sir Ernest Cassel deserves to be heartily congratulated on having come to the rescue of the banking community of Egypt, and of having saved them from what might have been a serious calamity by having finally brought the negotiations for a voluntary liquidation of the Cassa di Sconto to a successful conclusion. These negotiations were completed yesterday and a group of financiers have placed a quarter of a million at the disposal of the Cassa for the purpose of enabling the bank to meet its current liabilities and thus enabling the liquidation to be carried out gradually. The consequence is that the settlement recently foreshadowed is now assured.

div.head: LANCASHIRE AND THE EGYPTIAN CRISIS.
div.p: Although the recent bank suspension at Alexandria has not seriously affected either the export trade in raw cotton or the import trade in piece-goods there has been some anxiety in Manchester about the financial position in Egypt. It is known that land speculation has been freely carried on for some months past, and the fact that several banks have recently opened new branches at Cairo and Alexandria has probably led to the granting of credits which in other circumstances would have been unobtainable. The "Manchester Guardian" learns, however, upon good financial authority that the situation is now well in hand and that there need be no apprehension of any unfavourable developments such as would gravely affect Manchester trade interests.

div.head:
BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
(Aujourd'hui à midi).
div.p: A peine l'affaire de la Cassa di Sconto reçoitelle un commencement de solution, ue nous voici dans de nouveaux dangers. La situation critique de plusieurs établissements du Caire exerce sur notre bourse une influence défavorable. En ce qui concerne la Cassa, l'emprunt de 300.000 livres a été conclu et la banque ouvrira peut-être dès cet après-midi, en tous cas demain matin.

Malgré cette nouvelle, le prix de la Cassa n'a pas sensiblement augmenté Après avoir fait à l'ouverture 51 francs, il est revenu à 47 pour finir à 48.C'est d'ailleurs là, comme par le passé, un cours à peu près nominal, puisque les transactions sont toujours clairsemées.
L'ensemble de la cote est plutôt en baisse et les échanges n'ont pas eu d'importance.
L'Agricole s'avance de 7 3/4 à 7 13/16, la National Bank de 19 1/2 à 19 5/8, et l'Alexandria Water de 10 à 10 1/4.
En hausse également le Banco di Roma de 105 1/2 à 106, le Credit Franco-Egyptien de 4 à 4 1/16, la Banque d'Orient de 114 à 115 1/2, les Markets de 24 à 25.

Toutes les autres fluctuations sont dans le sens de la baisse : la Ramleh fléchit de 5 à 4 7 8, la Daïra de 13 5/8 à 13 1/2, l'Obligation Crédit Foncier de 313 l'ancienne et 265 la nouvelle à 312 et 264 1/2 respectivement, les Nungovich Hotels de 16 1/2 à 16, la Delta Land de 1 13/16 à 1 11/16, les Estates de 23/32 à 21/32, l'Urbaine de 3 7/8 à 3 3/4, la fondateur Comptoir de 3 1/4 à 3, la Levant de 5/8 à 9/16, la fondateur United de 2 1/4 à 2, les Ritz de 3/4 à 11/16 et la Levico de 7/16 à 3/8.
Sur le reste de la cote il n'y a pas de changement.
Le Comité de l'Association des Courtiers en valeurs d'Alexandrie vient d'afficher au tableau l'avis suivant:
le 4 Juillet.

"Le comité de l'association a été pèniblement impressionné par l'incident qui s'est produit à la Bourse de ce matin et qui a eu pour effet d'empêcher deux exécutions de titres dont le Comité avait été chargé. De pareils procédés sont de nature à jeter le discrédit sur notre Bourse et sur notre Association. Aussi le Comité espère t-il qu'il n'aura plus à les relever et il prie instamment Messieurs les Membres de l'Association de n'entraver d'aucune façon la marche normale des affaires. D'ailleurs chacun de nous est libre de ne pas se porter acheteur, mais sans avoir le droit de porter atteinte au libre arbitre de ses colleègues."
Le Comité.

C'est là le langage de la raison. Mais il nous semble qu'en prenant plus tôt le parti de combattre le désordre qui règne à la corbeille le Comité aurait pu éviter le discrédit de l'association. C'est maintenant un peu tard à notre avis pour remonter le courant.

La Commission internationale de législation se réunira vers la mi-novembre au ministère des Affaires Etrangères afin d'examiner les rapports relatifs à l'unification des transcriptions et inscriptions en Egypte, à la nouvelle loi sur la bourse et aux diverses modifications que le gouvernement égyptien propose d'introduire dans le code des tribunaux mixtes.
Les travaux terminés, la Commission saisira les Puissances du résultat de son examen.

div.head:
ALEXANDRIA.
THE BUILDING OF A CITY.
REGULATIONS FOR CONSTRUCTION.
div.p: By Roberts Williams F. R. I. B. A.
III.

In my last paper, mention was made of a rumour that the Municipality was about to make a regulation to the effect that all persons intending to build were to deposit plans at the office of the Municipality and to obtain the sanction of the authorities before beginning to build. I have just had placed in my hand confirmation of that rumour, a copy of the regulation which it is intended should remain in force until the promulgation of definite regulations. That is to say, we are to have a kind of stop-gap for something definite in a country where indefiniteness reigns paramount. How long shall we have to wait none can tell.

Six years ago I enquired at the Municipality for the Alexandria building regulations. 1 was politely informed that there were none, but that they had been in consideration for one or two years. Later on when I had matured my plans for a building, I enquired again but was told that the regulations were still in abeyance. But a move is now made for which I am sure the citizens of Alexandria and in particular the regular architectural practitioneers should be thankful. The gist of the proposed interim regulations is as follows :—

No buildings are to be erected and no enlargement, heightening, rearrangement or repairs or any work whatsoever is to be undertaken to existing buildings withio the area of the city of Alexandria, before plans are submitted and approved of by the Municipality.
The following requisitions are made.

list.item: Complete sections both vertical and horizontal with elevations ot the intended building.

div.p: When all these documents, which will entail considerable expense to the proprietors are handed to the Municipality in duplicate, it will, in 15 days (not 15 weeks or months) but expeditiously in 15 days (dans le délai de 15 jours) make known its approval or otherwise, and herein comes the troublesome point. The London building act only requires a notice of two days and the applicant has not to wait for approval. Judging from what I have seen of building in Alexandria during the last six years it can safely be said that the majority of buildings are erected with little or no calculations as to their strength.

Formerly a building of three storeys was a high one in Alexandria, now they are of five or six storeys and I have heard off the possibility of the erection of a ten storey building. Recent calamitous accidents have proved that the Alexandrian mason is not acquainted with the workmanship required to ensure the stability of high, thick walls. He is deficient in the knowledge of bond. Reinforced concrete or béton armé and steel construction specially for floor and weight bearing structures, are coming much into vogue, these and the taller buildings now being built demand the setting forth of an absolute minimum as to thickness of walls, strength of joists etc. There is also the question of mortar, which, together with bond, is of the greatest importance in good building; but on these points the proposed regulations are silent.

Asking for plans before setting forth general regulations as to building, is certainly, as I said before, putting the cart before the horse. How are the officers of the Municipality to decide whether our plans are correct, say, as to the matter of thickness of walls? Have they secret codes, or will they make their decisions in a haphazard fashion? If they have a code—a means of deciding the strength of structures—then nothing could be easier than to draw up a general regulation in accordance therewith. This is thrown out as a suggestion, as, so far as I understand, this proposed regulation has not yet received the sanction of publication in the Official Journal.
As to an interim regulation the following is also offered as a suggestion.
1. Every intending builder to furnish a notice on a printed form giving (a) the position of his building (b) the number of floors and height (c) name and address of the builder.
This is all that is generally required in London with its population of five millions. The following are the regulations as to notices of the London building act

"Every building notice shall state the situation, area, height, number of storeys and intended use of the building or structure and the number of buildings or structures, if more than one and the particulars of the proposed work and the name and address of the person giving the notice and those of the owner then in possession, and of the occupier of the building or structure or of its site or intended site.
All works in progress at the same time to, in, or on the same building or structure may be included in one building notice."
No plans are asked for save in the matter of public buildings or special structures.
As the Municipality here is the sanitary as well as the building authority (in London the building and sanitary authorities are separate) the following may be added to the building regulation.
2. A block plan to be submitted showing the position of the building, the adjacent streets, the drains and connection with public sewers.
The plan might be drawn on a space reserved for it on the notice paper.
But while one agrees to the issuing of tentative regulations, no time should be lost in formulating and publishing regulations as to construction etc.
The following is the text of the regulations.
ARTICLE PREMIER.

Les mesures et prescriptions suivantes seront appliquées à titre transitoire en attendant la promulgation d'un règlement définitif concernant les routes ainsi que le contrôle des constructions dans la Ville d'Alexandrie.

Nul ne pourra construire, agrandir, surélever, réconforter on réparer dans le périmètre de la ville d'Alexandrie à quelque titre ou dans quelque limite que ce soit des maisons, édifices, mure de clôture, balcons, perrons, trottoirs ou tout ouvrage, avant que les plans de l'ouvrage projeté ne soient soumis à la Municipalité et approuvés par elle et avant d'avoir reçu du Service du Tanzim l'autorisation de l'alignement en ce qui concerne les ouvrages bordant la voie publique.
Les dessins à présenter en double expédition par les intéressés devront comprendre:

list.item: Les plans du rez-de-chaussée et divers étages avec élévations et coupes à 1'échelle de un pour cent.
Un plan d'ensemble de l'emplacement à construire, des voies qui le bordent on l'avoisinent, ainsi que des dispositions de drainage à l'échelle de un pour mille.
Les plans des solivages et toitures à l'échelle de un pour cent.
Des détails cotés à l'échelle de un pour dix de tontes autres parties essentielles de constructions, (piliers, colonnes, consoles et sections des fondations).

div.p: Les intéressés anront en outre à soumettre à la Municipalité le cahier des charges relatif aux travaux à exécutor.

L'Administration devra, dans le délai de 15 jours à partir de la présentation des dessins et cahier des charges ci-dessus, manifester son approbation et délivrer en conséquence la roksa de construction et d'alignemeut Au cas où ces dessins et cahier des charges n'auraient pas été agréés, la Municipalité devra daus le même délai en faire part aux intéressés et leur communiquer les observations qu'elle croira devoir formuler.
Aucune modification au plan approuvé par la Municipalité on an cahier des charges ne pourra être apportée sans l'agrément écrit de cette dernière.

Les agents préposés au contrôle des constructions auront libre accès à tout moment aux ouvrages et constateront toute inobservation des plans approuvés ou da cahier des charges et dresseront les procès-verbaux y relatifs dans les formes et avec les mêmes sanctions adoptées en matière de contravention au règlement du Tanzim.
La Municipalité pourra retirer dans ce cas l'autorisation et empêcher toute continuation des travaux.

L'autorisation donnée par la Municipalité pas plus que l'approbation des plans et cahier des charges ou le contrôle exercé par ces agents, n'implique pour elle aucune responsabilité, laquelle demeure pleine et entière à la charge des intéressés.
Art. II.
Le présent arrêté qui ne déroge pas aux Lois et Règlements existants entrera en vigueur 30 jours après sa publication au "Journal Officiel."
Fait à Alexandrie, le.....

div.head: EGYPTIAN WEATHER.
div.p: The Survey Department of the Ministry of Finance has issued the following report on the weather for last month:—

Throughout the month the weather has been settled and fine. The barometer was somewhat above normal at most stations in Egypt and the Sudan, but slightly below at European stations in the Eastern Mediterranean. Temperature was rather low at most stations of our area. As usual in this month there has been no rainfall in Egypt. On the Sudan plains the rain appears to have been in defect, and at Suakin it failed altogether.

On the first of the month temperature was somewhat high, but with a rise of pressure it fell a little until another fall of pressure gave an increase of temperature again upon the 4th. Conditions were then normal until another fall of pressure on the 10th. and 11th. gave warm dry southerly winds. The temperatures experienced were not, however, excessive and regular Khamsin conditions were not recorded except at Suez. From the 12th to the end of the month Egyptian weather conditions were steady. The highest temperature of the month at Egyptian stations occurred on the 4th or the 11th and the lowest about the 9th.
In the Sudan regular summer conditions are established. At Khartoum on the 2nd there was a violent "habub" which is stated by newspaper reports to have done considerable damage in the town.
The Blue Nile and the Sobat were late in beginning their permanent rise and are still below their normal levels. It appears that the Nile Flood of this year will be somewhat behind time.

div.head: SERIOUS CONFLAGRATION.
div.p: Damanhour, Friday.
A terrible conflagration broke out yesterday at Abou Khousha. The entire village was burnt and four persons perished in the flames.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner "Khephren" arrived this morning from Liverpool via Gibraltar, Algiers Philippeville and Malta with passengers, mails general cargo.

div.head: LOCAL CRICKET MATCH.
div.p: A most exciting cricket match was played yesterday afternoon at Mustapha between a team from the ships in harbour, arranged by Capt. Runton, and a team of the Dublin Fusiliers, captained by Colour Serjeant Byrne. The sailors started rather badly, Teppet being dismissed for a duck, and Fisher and Purvis only put on 6 and 4 respectively, but the tail wagged merrily and useful scores were made by Captains Waterworth, Runton, Findlay, and Bell, all of whom played a very steady game. The play of the Dublin Fusiliers was even throughout, though the team was somewhat weakly constituted. With the last man in the Fusiliers drew level with the 70 of Captain Runton's team and the excitement was intense. A fairly fast ball from Teppet found Wylleye on the spot, and it was well driven towards the boundary, but, unfortunately for the latter and his side, Captain Findlay was there, and the ball was firmly secured in his hands, thus bringing a good match to a dead heat.

div.head: RIFLE SHOOTING.
div.p: The return match, H.M.S. "Diana," versus B.R.C., was shot yesterday afternoon, when the naval team showed much improved form and beat their opponents by 32 points. Scores:—

div.head:
ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB.
GYMKHANA.
div.p: A Gymkhana is being arranged by several members of the Alexandria Sporting Club for to-morrow afternoon, commencing at 3 p.m., the programme of which will be as follows :—
Bending Race, Lloyd Lindsay, Polo Match; Hack Scurry; Stick and Ball Polo; Pig Sticking; Tentpegging.
Members are aocordingly invited to take part. For each event prizes will be distributed. Post Entries. Entrance P.T. 10.
As the polo ground will be used for the Gymkhana the golf course will not be open tomorrow afternoon.

General Sir Harry Aubrey Maclean, K C.M.G., whose capture by Raisuli has given a new turn to Moorish politics, was born in 1848 and was formerly in the 69th Foot. He is Colonel of the Sultan of Morocco's Bodyguard.
Mr. Edward Dicey, C B, has contributed an article on Sir Auckland Colvin's defence of Lord Cromer to the July number of the "Nineteenth Century and After."
Mr. A. P. Mack, Managing Director of the Egyptian Land & General Trust, Ltd., is leaving for England by the P.&O. "Britannia" on Tuesday next, on two months leave of absence.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE.
div.p: La Délégation Municipale s'est réunie hier après-midi, sous la présidence de S.E. Schiess Pacha.

Réunie avec le Comité spécial chargé de l'examen des demandes présntées pour les nouveaux postes d'ingénieurs, la Délégation a adopté les conclusions de ce Comité et a nommé les ingénieurs proposés par ce Comité.

—Un monument ancien ayant été mis à jour, en pratiquant des fouilles dans l'emplacement affecté an nouveau Cimetière catholique, la Délégation sur la proposition du Comité du Musée,proposera à la Commission l'ouverture d'un crédit de 100 livres pour faire des fonilles dans ce terrain.

—Le Ministère des Travaux Publics ayant offert une somme 1,000 livres comme contribution du Gouvernement dans la construction d'une nouvelle route en corniche allant aux casernes de Ras-el-Tin, la Délégation en raison des sommes considérables que cette route et sa canalisation coûteront à la ville—7,000 livres environ—espère que le Gouvernement voudra tout au moins doubler la contribution par lui proposée.

—La Délégation a adjugé à M. Toussaint Suzzarini la fourniture de 10,000 mètres linéaires de bordures de trottoir, au prix de P.T. 21 le mètre. Les offres pour la fourniture de tuyaux en grès et pour l'égoût de la route de Kom-el-Dick ont été renvoyées aux services pour rapport

—Conformément à une proposition de M. Monfront, jardinier en chef de la Municipalité et de l'avis conforme du Comité des arbres et plantations, la Délégation a décidé la construction de serres au jardin Nouzha et a accepté les offres d'une maison belge pour la construction de ces serres au prix de 20,000 francs.
—La Délégation a renvoyé au Comité des Travaux publics une note de l'Ingénieur en chef relative au déplacement de la nouvelle gare de Bab-el-Hadid, à Kom-el-Dick.

—Elle a accepté. la cession de deux rues à Moharrem Bey, faite par la Société des Entreprises Urbaines et Rurales, à condition que cette Société consente à payer le prix de la bordure des trottoirs, après avoir macadamisé ces rues à ses frais.

—Un échange d'idées a eu lieu au sujet des adjudications Municipales. On a émis l'avis qu'il ne faudrait pas s'arrêter toujours à l'offre la plus basse, car des fois une offre un peu plus élevée peut présenter de meilleures conditions et garanties. Plusieurs fois des maisons sérieuses s'abstiennent de concourir à certaines adjudications, plutôt que de faire des offres trop basses qui ne leur permettraient pas de faire un travail satisfaisant
—La Délégation a décidé de changer le système des adjudications et a chargé l'Ingénieur en chef de faire un rapport à ce sujet.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le Caire, Jeudi 4 Juillet.

Le taux: de l'escompte libre à Londres est resté hier à 3 3/8 pour cent. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a baissé de 1/8 à 84 3/8. L'Unifiée est demeurée inchangée à 100 1/2. La National Bank a rétrogradé de 1/8 à 19 3/4. La Daïra a avancé de 1/8 à 14. L'Agrieole s'est maintenue à 8. La Delta Light est restée invariée à 9.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a perdu 3 frames à 684 et la Banque d'Athènes l franc à 113.

Ici, nous avons eu, ce matin, une séance calme, avec affaires très limitées et tendance générale à la faiblesse. L'allure tâtonnante des places d'Occident a fait aisément sentir son influence sur notre marché, et le terrain gagné hier par les valeurs dirigeantes a été reperdu et au delà.
Ainsi la National est revenue à 19 7/16 et l'Agricole à 7 11/16. La Cassa di Sconto a été marquée 50 l'action ancienne et 58 la nouvelle. La Banque d'Orient s'est raffermie à 112.
La Daïra s'est alourdie à 13 7/8. L'Immobiliére a été cotée 350 ex-coupon et sa part 530, ex-coupon également.
Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire se sont tassées à 183. La Brasserie des Pyramides est tombée à 100 et sa part à 33.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovich ont été bien tenus à 16. Les Egyptian ont faibli à 4 1/2, les Upper Egypt à 2 13/16, Ies ^National à 2 1/2 et les Ritz à 0 11/16.

Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land a été ramenée à 1 13/16, les Estates à 0 11/16 et leur part à 5 1/2, les New Egyptian à 14 sh. 9. Les Markets se sont raffermis à 23 sh. 6 et les Khedivial Mail à 23 sh.

Il se confirme que les négociations engagées entre le conseil d'administration de la Cassa di Sconto et le syndicat des Banques auraient définitivement abouti. La signature des conventions concernant la conclusion de l'emprunt qui permettra à la Cassa de rouvrir ses guichets serait appelée à avoir lieu aujourd'hui. Dans ceu cas, la Cassa ferait sa réouverture demain matin ou bien dans l'après-midi, ou bien encore samedi matin si quelque retard se produisait dans l'accomplissement des dernières formalités.

Par décision du Comité de l'Association des courtiers en valeurs d'Alexandrie, les seances de la Bourse de cette ville commencent à 10 h. 30 du matin pour clôturer à midi, au lieu de 11 h. 30. Cette mesure a été appliquée dès hier à Alexandrie; mais, contrairement à ce que l'en affirmait, elle n'a pas été mise aujourd'hui en viguer au Caire.
Ce changement d'horaire ne rencontre pas l'approbation de "The Egyptian Gazette" d'Alexandrie, qui fait les observations suivantes dans son No. d'hier.

"On a beaucoup remarqué ce matin que l'ouverture a eu lieu en hauese que le marché est resté soutenu presque jusqu'à la fin. C'est à partir de 11 h. 1/2, c'est-à-dire à l'heure habituelle de clôture, que la faiblesse reprenant le dessus a entrainé une baisse partielle plus ou moius sensible. Il est très probable que, devant l'inaction persistante de notre marché, les Comités des courtiers ep valeurs, tant d'Alexandrie que du Caire, reviendront à l'ancien horaire, qui était très rationnel et amplement suffisant. Mais pourquoi tous ces changements subits, sans avis préalable ? "
Nous détachons de notre correspondance de Londres, en date du 28 Juin dernier, le passage suivant:

"Notre marché à continué cette seipaine à être actif. Les affaires ont été nombreuses et il y a eu en général une reprise coasidérable. La National Bank a passé de 16 5/8 à 19 13/16 après avoir fait jusqu'à 20 3/4 au pips haut. L'Agricole a avancé de 7 5/16 à 7 15 16, après 8 5/8 demandée au plus haut. La Land Bank a repris de 6 1/2 à 7 1/4 pour finir à 7, et l'Union Foncière, de 4 3/8, a fait jusqu'à 5 1/8 pour clôturer à 4 7/8. En Daïra, des paquets de titres out changé de mains entre 12 1/2 et 14 1/4, le dernier cours étant 13 7/8. La Delta Light a fait 8 au plus bas le 22 courant; il y a eu ensuite une reprise considérable jusqu'à 9 3/4, suivie de réalisations qui ont ramené le cours à 9 1/8.

"Sur la Delta Land, des transactions ont eu lieu au plus bas à 1 1/2; une forte demande s'est fait sentir hier jusqu'a 2 3/16, mais on a clôturé plus faible aujourd'hui à 1 15/16. Un bon nombre de transactions ont été pratiquées en Markets, qui ont passé de 23/6 a 24/6. En Estates, après des transactions jusqu'à 16/3, il y a eu des achats suivis jusqu'à 20/; mais aujourd'hui, par suite de la vente d'un paquet considérable, le cours a été ramené 4 £0 29/32. La New Egyptian a aussi été en demande, plusieurs centaines de titres ayant changé de mains entre 16/-et 16-9. L'Aboukir a avancé de 1 7/16 à 1 9/16, sur un bon nombre de transactions. Les United Lands ont été négligées, mais ce soir il y avait acheteurs à £ 0 7/16."
Carnet de l' actionnaire.

On annonce que le coupon de 3 sh., moins l'income tax, fixé par l'assemblée générale ordinaire de l'Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Co., tenue le 22 Juin dernier, sera payable à partir du 15 Juillet courant à la National Bank of Egypt

Une communication officieuse de la Corporation of Western Egypt Ltd. dément les rumeurs suivant lesquelles les disponibilités de la Société ne seraient pas suffisantes pour procéder à l'achèvement du railway entre les Oasis et la Haute-Egypte. Les fonds dont dispose la Compagnie permettraient non-seulement d'atteindre ce but et d'assurer tout le matériel roulant nécessaire à l'exploitation, ainsi que les autres dépenses, mais laisseraient encore un solde considérable pour le développement de l'agriculture dans les Oasis. D'après les demiers rapports, la ligne est achevée jusqu'au kilomètre 137-800; il ne reste que 56 k. 200 m. à terminer pour atteindre le village de Khargeh.

div.head: Alexandria General Produce Association
Section Contonniere
div.p: RÉSUMÉ DES RÉSPONDES REÇUES EN JUIN 1907

La température en Juin dans la Basse-Egypte a été chaude et favorable à la plante, qui a fait de grands progrès dans son développement. De presque partout il se confirme que le retard précédemment mentionné est en grande partie regagné.
En général aussi la plante se présente saine et vigoureuse.

Des apparitions sporadiques de vers ont été constantées dans plusieurs localités, mais en quantités minimes. Dans tous les cas, la promptitude avee laquelle on a procédé à leur destruction a fait que nulle part il ne s'est produit de dégâts.
L'eau est suffisante.
De la Haute Egypte les rapports sont satisfaisants. On y parle bien encore d'une quinzaine de jours de retard, mais la plante est en bon état et toute cette partie du pays est indemne du ver.
Au Fayoum, les cultures, par contre, semblent aussi advancées que l'année dernère, et quant aux vers on n'en a presque pas vus.
L'eau est suffisante, et même abondante.
Pur le Comité
Les Président en fonction
P. FENDERL.
Alexandrie, le 30 Juin 1907.

div.p: The British Legation here is doing all that is possible to secure the release of Sir H. Maclean. The Sultan's representative is assisting heartily. The Legation has received a letter from Sir H. Maclean stating that he is well and is being kindly treated. (Reuter)
The Khmes tribe are keeping an eye on Kaid Maclean and Raisuli with a view to liberating the former, or sharing the ransom with the latter. (Havas)

Lord Selborne has issued an important memorandum forcibly urging the advantages of a federation. He declares that the decision cannot be postponed in view of the intimate interdependency of the Colonies regarding railways, customs, and the native questions. (Reuter)
The animosities of the Hungarians and Croatians are becoming more embittered daily.
The Premier has announced that the occupation of Bosnia and Herzegovina will be permanent. (Reuter)
On the occasion of thé Garibaldi centenary, the King has signed amnesties for political offences and lèse majesté. (Reuter)
President Marcora eulogised Garibaldi in the Chamber of Deputies. The fete was celebrated throughout Italy with great enthusiasm. (Havas)
At an official banquet the vice-president of the Paris Municipaity proposed the health of the Emperor. (Havas)
Petroff, the assassin of M. Petkoff, has been sentenced to death. (Havas)

div.head: OCCUPATION OF EGYPT
THE SECRET HISTORY.
div.p: II
Mr. Wilfrid Blunt's Secret History of the Occupation of Egypt, is full of passages of extreme local interest.

The following is an extract from his journal of 1887, January 31, Cairo.—Called on Princess Nazli She is at least as clever as she is pretty. Her conversation would be brillant in any society in the world. She told us a great deal that interested us about Arabi, for whom she had, and I am glad to see still has, a great culte, talking of his singleness of mind and lamenting his overthrow. He was not a good enough soldier, she said, and has too good a heart. These were his faults. If he had been a violent man like my grandfather, Mohemet Ali, he would have taken Tewfik and all of us to the Citadel and cut our heads off—and he would have been now happily reigning, or if he could have got the Khedive to go on honestly with him he would have made a great king of him. Arabi was the first Egyptian Minister who made the Europeans obey him. In his time at least the Mohammedans held up their heads and the Greeks, and Italians did not dare transgress the law. I have told Tewfik this more than once. Now there is nobody to keep order. The Egyptians alone are kept under by the police and the Europeans do as they like.

div.head: MUZZLING THE PRESS.
div.p: Sir Auckland Colvin knew how to muzzle the Press. Mr. Blunt writes:—

It will perhaps be as well to explain here the way in which the London Press and especially Reuter's News Agency was at this time manipulated officially at Cairo, and made subservent to the intrigues of diplomacy.

Very few London newspapers had any regular correspondent in Egypt, the "Times" and the "Pall Mall Gazette" being, as far as I know, the only two that were thus provided. Both, as far as politics were concerned, were practically in the hands of Sir Auckland Colvin, the English financial controller, an astute Indian official, with the traditions of Indian diplomacy strongly developed in his political practice. He had some experience of journalism, having been connected with the "Pioneer" in India, an Anglo-Indian Journal of pronounced imperialistic type with which he was still in correspondence. He was also Morley's regular correspondent in the "Pall Mall Gazette" and had through him the ear of the Government.

The importance of this unavowed connection will be seen later when he made it his business to bring about English intervention. Lastly, on all important diplomatic matters he inspired the "Times" whose regular correspondent, Scott, depended on him for his information.

With regard to Reuter and Havas, the telegraphic agencies, both were heavily subventioned by the Anglo French Financial control, receiving £1,000 a year each, charged on the thin resources of the Egyptian Budget. Reuter especially was the servant and mouthpiece of the English Agency and the telegrams despatched to London were under Mallet's censorship. This sort of manipulation of the organs of public news in the interests of our diplomacy, exists in nearly all the capitals where our agents reside and is a potent instrument for misleading the home public. The influence is not as a rule exercised by any direct payment, but by favour given in regard to secret and valuable information, and also largely, by social amenities. In Egypt it has always within my knowledge been supreme, except at moments of extreme crisis when the body of special press correspondents at Cairo or Alexandria has been too numerous to be kept under official control. In ordinary times our officials have had complete authority both as to what news should be sent to London, and what news, received from London, should be published in Egypt. It is very necessary that this, the true condition of things should be steadily borne in mind by historians when they consult the newspaper files of these years in search of information.

div.head: EGYPT AND GLASDSTONE.
div.p: An exceptionally interesting passage showing Gladstone's views of Egypt is quoted from an article contributed by that politician to the "Nineteenth Century" in 1877. Gladstone writes:—"Our first site in Egypt" he writes "be it by larceny or be it by emption, will be the almost certain egg of a North African Empire that will grow and grow till another Victoria and another Albert, titles ofthe lake sources of the White Nile, will come within our borders and till we finally join hands across the equator with Natal and Cape Town, to say nothing of the Transvaal and the Orange River on the South of Abyssinia or Zanzibar, to be swallowed by way of viaticum on our journey and then, with a great empire in each of the four quarters of the world—we may be territorially content but less than ever at our ease."
Mr. Gladstone's views of Sir Auckland Colvin, and Sir E. Malet's work in Egypt are thus noticed in the report of an interview between Mr. Blunt and the Liberal statesman:

"I delivered all Arabi's messages about the slave trade and the other projects of reform, and then went on to explain Colvin's position and Malet's. He said almost, pathetically, "What can we do?" They are esteemed public servants and have received honours for their work in Egypt. He insisted upon fhe word honours.

div.head: MR. BLUNT'S IMPORTANCE.
div.p: Mr. Blunt is fully convinced of his enormous importance. The italicised sentences given below are delightful samples cf his conceit:—

With the regular press correspondents he knew how to deal, but he could not deal with us, who were independent writers, or exercise the smallest censorship on our opinions. There was an end therefore to the close intimacy I had, up to that point, in spite of small disagreements, had with the agency. This was unfortunate as it threw Mallet, who always needed to loan on some one stronger than himself into other and less conciliatory hands.

On the 31st of January, the very day of the change of Ministry at Paris I find a note to the effect that I went into Cairo and saw Colvin and had a remarkable conversation with him. This has become of great historical importance throngh subsequent events for it marks the date within a few days of the change of temper of the English Financial control, and with it of our diplomacy towards Egyptian nationalism, and also fixes upon Colvin, what is indeed his due, the chief responsibility of the rupture which afterwards through his contriving came about

div.head: WOLSELY AND EGYPT.
div.p: We extract the following from an account of Mr. Blunt's interview with Lord Wolseley:—

He volunteered the information that he had been consulted two or three times during the winter with a view to immediate occupation He assured me, however, that nobody wanted. to intervene, that the Occupation of Egypt would be most unpopular with the Army, and that he himself should he very sorry to have to go there. He would far rather the Egyptians should disband their army and trust to European protection, but I told him I could not advise them to do that, and that people were not often attacked who really meant fighting. He said well of course there is no such thing as honour in war, and if there were really any question of fighting, they ought not to trust us more than other people." He then talked about the various military routes to Cairo, Bonaparte's by the left bank of the Nile, and especially the desert way between the Suez Canal and the Delta, so that I felt pretty sure that if troops were landed it would be on that side. But I was careful to give him no information which could be of the least use to him, and 1 only laughed when he half seriously asked me whether I would go with him and show him the way if it came to a campaigne.

My impression of Wolseley was of a good smart soldier, an Irishman with a rough touch of brogue, good humoured and I should fancy enterprising. But he does not impress me as a man of genius—what Napoleon used to call a "général a dix mille hommes." It is worth noting that in writing to Sheikh Mohamed Abdou, through my secretary Sabunji, soon after this conversation, I alluded to the danger there might be, in case of intervention, of their being attacked from the Ismailia side, and I believe it was in consequence of this hint that the lines of Tel-el-Kebir were begun to be traced by Arabi's order.

div.head: EXCAVATION OF MEMPHIS.
APPEAL FOR FUNDS.
div.p: An important letter, signed by Sir Robert Hensley, Sir William Richmond, Professor Mahaffy, and Professor Ernest Gardner, appealing for assistance for the British School of Archæology in Egypt in the work of excavating Memphis, appeared in the press last week:—

Sir,—One of the greatest capitals in the ancient world has been left untouched in its dust, although the ground is visited by thousands of tourists every year. Memphis whose history extends over the whole coarse of Egyptian civilization, has never yet been explored. It contained the finest school of Egyptian art, and in antiquity and wealth it was unrivalled. But most of it has gradually passed under the plough, and to rescue what yet remains is most needful before it further disappears. Great national undertakings, as of France in the clearing of Delphi, or of Germany at Olympia, can never be done under our form of government, which ignores such intellectual conquests. Scientific research by England is mainly matter of public association; and it is to the public that the British School of Archaeology in Egypt must look for the needful support of the excavations which it is going to undertake (by permission of the Egyptian Government) at Memphis.

The vast temple of Ptab, the temple of Isis, the sumptuous dwelling of the sacred Apis, the rich temple of Aphrodite in the Phoenician and foreign quarter—all these were the celebrated sights of Memphis in the Greek age; and beneath the ruins of some of these must lie the monuments of the beginning of the Egyptian kingdom, from Menes onward. The sites of these temples are plainly visible amid the mounds. The area of them is equal to the whole of Karnak, the southern capital of the land. It is known definitely where the search must be made for the statues, the sculptures, and the records of the oldest capital of Egypt. To clear the temple sites is estimated to cost about £3,000 a year for 15 or 20 years. This, we hope, may be possible as a national enterprise; and, as half of the sculptures discovered will be granted by the Egyptian Government, it should reward any nation that undertakes the work. The greater scope, of the complete clearance of all the ancient capital, would require about half a million, and can hardly be hoped for unless supported by one of the great masters of industry or finance. But we trust that the ordinary British method of subscription—from the traditional guinea upward—will enable us at least to clear the metropolitan temples of Egypt, and not to feel ashamed in view of the splendid labour of excavation accomplished by other countries. To be obliged to invite the assistance of foreign support in this task would prevent our reaping the reward of the gratuitous labour given by Professor Flinders Petrie and his helpers.

The secretary of the British School, at University College, London (Gower-street), will give any further information, at the exhibition of the discoveries of the present year, July 1 to 27, held at the college, where also the publications given to subscribers may be seen.
We remain, Sir, yours obediently,
W.B. RICHMOND.
J.P. MAHAFFY.
E A. GARDNER.
R.M. HENSLEY (Chairman)

div.head: EGYPTIAN LIFE AND SCENERY.
LONDON ART EXHIBITIONS.
div.p: (From a Special Correspondent).
London, June 28.

The joint exhibition of pictures on Egyptian subjects by Miss Nellie Hadden and Miss McCracken at Maclean's Gallery has already received notice in these columns; and this week we have had the pleasure of inspecting the works of two other artists who have approached the subjects of Egyptian life and scenery from very widely diverging points of view.

The few weeks spent by Miss Sybil Dowie this winter in Helouan were her first introduction to the land of splendid colouring and atmosphere; and the work she has done during that sport period is a distinct departure from her former efforts, which have been almost invariably devoted to portraiture. Her education in art includes several years spent in Paris where at one time she studied at the Gulian school under Bougereau and again with Lazar. She has already made a certain reputation for her portraits in both oils and pastels, and has had various of her works accepted by the Royal Academy and the Salone, while one occupies a place in the permanent gallery of Bolton's Hall.

Unlike most other Egyptian artists, Miss Dowie has chosen the mediums of both oil and pastel in her present exhibition of "sketches of Egypt" which has occupied one of the rooms of the Doré Gallery, and has recorded her impressions in a bolder and more impressionist style than we have been accustomed to. Her pastels are sombre and quiet in colouring and are mostly confined to interiors and bazaar scenes; but her sketches in oil, if lacking in detail, are very spontaneous records of sunshine and colour. Seeing that Miss Dowie's stay in Egypt last winter was only of six weeks' duration, her exhibition is in every way creditable to her, and if she sees her way to extending her acquaintance with the country which has impressed her so favourably, we may hope in future to count her among the valuable exponents of its many beauties.

The work of Mr.W.Tyndal is of a very different genre. Already he ranks among the first of our Egyptian artists, and his knowledge of the country and its history adds a deeper zest to many of his pictures beyond their mere beauty of form and colouring. So minute and perfect is the detail of some of the wall paintings delineated by him, that their history lies like an open book before those who have eyes to see, and yet the intricate detail is given with so much subtlety and sense of proportion that it never detracts from the effect of the main scheme. His long stay in the neighbourhood of Thebes this winter has resulted in many a picture of the wonderful tombs and temples there, as well as at Karnak and Luxor; and he has also included in his present collection some very fine and marvellously proportioned studies of the temple of Abu Simbel. There are also some wonderful reproductions of wall paintings:—the "Isis suckling Horus" from Abydos, and others from the Temple of Amada, and the Tomb of Nacht at Thebes. Very interesting too are the coloured casts of Senseneb and Aahmes from the Temple of Hatshepsu, which have only been procured with the greatest of care and infinite trouble.

Mr. Tyndale's love of architecture and mastery of perspective are shown to their best in his painting of many of the native streets of Cairo and elsewhere. No other artist has a more pleasing sense of colour and effect, none can reproduce more delicately the luminous shadows, the varied colouring, and the fine stone carving and musharabieh work which gives these streets such character. Notable for these qualities are his pictures taken in the Bab el Zuela and the Khaleeg, while others of the same sort are entitled "The Sheik's House" and "After the midday Prayer."

Early in the forthcoming autumn, Mr. Tyndale hopes to place before the public, his book entitled "Below the Cataracts" which will be all the more valuable for including some sixty reproductions of his pictures.

From Liverpool we hear most favourable accounts of the success of Mr. A. 0. Lamplough's exhibition at Messrs. Giryndley and Palmer's Galleries. His pictures are so well known in Cairo circles that it is hardly necessary to dwell further on the properties which have made them so popular. Those to whom the land of the Pharaohs is a sealed book may learn much of its beauties as seen by Mr. Lamplough's eyes; and those who know and love the land are quick to appreciate his efforts and to realize their value. Mr. Lainplough intends bringing his pictures to London in July, when doubtless he will still further increase his reputation.

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION.
THE NEW COMMAND.
div.p: A Cairo vernacular organ makes the following interesting comments on the new command:—

The last thing heard of the Duke of Connaught in connection with Egypt was extremely interesting. It was rumoured that as Commander-in-Chief of the British Garrisons in the Mediterranean Stations he has made up his mind to live in Egypt during the term of his command. According to official arrangements the central office for this military command will be at Malta, where the Duke is not a stranger. But we have been repeatedly told that his Royal Highness prefers Alexandria to Valetta and will make our great seaport his head quarters. Egyptians will be glad to see a Royal Duke among the distinguished rulers in their land.

Some of our readers, however, look upon the new arrangement with the Duke of Connaught as Commander in Chief, from another point of view. To certain minds the mere fact that Egypt is now included in matters military with Malta and Gibraltar and Cyprus in this new arrangement, and that no separate command is left for Egypt, means that the British Government now take it for granted that Egypt and Malta are both possessions of England in the same way. Whether the new command was created to convey this meaning or for other purposes, some of those who interpret actions and events are emphatic in their assertion that England has definitely, but stealthily, counted Egypt among her dominions beyond the sea. Other events and proceedings of recent date are equally eloquent in pointing out the same moral, but no absolute conviction can be claimed. By all means let a Royal Duke come and stay here. Let a firm and powerful Government be established on a permanent footing, for Egypt is tired ot a temporary arrangement.
REMARKS.
The general weather conditions are unchanged. The barometer is steady.

Des prix réduits seront accordés aux passagers par plusieurs hotels à Constantinople, comme aussi au Phalère, Athènes, etc., et si les passagers en première classe désirent rester à bord à Constantinople et retourner par le même vapeur, ils auront la faculté de le faire en payant Fcs. 10 par jour pour leur nourriture.

La durée de la validité des billets est de trois semaines à compter de l'arrivée au port de destination. Leur validité ne peut pas être prolongée sauf contre paiement de la différence entre le prix de ces billets et celui des billets ordinaires.
